threads.content: i wanna know whats the most used port hacking tool?

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: I wanna know what you think "port hacking" is?

threads.author: youpaki
threads.content: Ports serve as entry points for communication between devices and are associated with specific services or protocols, such as HTTP port 80 or SSH port 22. When improperly secured, these ports can become an attack

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: Sure, but what is "port hacking"?

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: There's port scanning... there's attacks on specific services...

threads.author: youpaki
threads.content: refers to the act of exploiting vulnerabilities or weaknesses

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: I've never heard anyone call that "port hacking"....

threads.author: youpaki
threads.content: everything has a different name

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: regardless, back to your original question now that I know what you're asking: There isn't a single specific tool that gets used for exploiting vulnerabilities. Probably the closest thing to a universal tool would be Metasploit, but that might only help you with 20% of the vulnerabilities out there...

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: For example if you want to write an exploit that takes advantage of a buffer overflow, you need to understand how the system works at a low level, and be able to set up and make syscalls directly from binary shellcode

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: It is also going to be important for malware development if you want to write something that attempts to properly bypass detection (not just silly Python malware)

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: The book "the art of exploitation" has a very good, very thorough explanation of why they're important, and how to utilize them

threads.author: .eevee
threads.content: Also Grey Hat Hacking, latest edition

threads.author: .eevee
threads.content: Ericksons book was one of my first purchases 10+ years ago

threads.author: .eevee
threads.content: The fundamentals haven't changed in 50 years

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: It's a solid read still for binary exploitation

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: the rest of it is so far out of date that it's laughable, but that part is solid

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: yup

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: same techniques that worked on a PDP1 will work just fine on a modern processor

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: Probably what you're looking at is actually doing QLora training for the model

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: It really depends on the size of the model you start with

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: and how much time you're willing to let it run for

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: You could try doing the training in a free-tier Google Colab session, but that is going to introduce a bit of extra complexity

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: In that case it really just depends on how much GPU memory you have, and how big your base model is

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: Well, really all that matters there is your video card. The 3070 only has 8GB of video memory, so you're going to be limited to fairly small models, and you'll need to split your training data up into small chunks

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: sure, but really all you're doing is breaking up your training data and sending the model and part of the training data to each host in the farm, so each one needs to have sufficient memory to handle that

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: It really depends on how much training per data chunk you do. My guess is that with a smaller model you could probably break the data into 1-2GB chunks and train on each chunk for an hour or so

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: so ~20-40ish hours of training

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: Start at the beginning and work your way through each topic

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: To make sure your expectations are set properly, I will tell you, this is not a quick path. I would suggest that you should be spending weeks to months on most sections, with lots of additional learing outside of just the resources provided on the roadmap

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: I would expect that, starting from a beginner level, you're probably going to want to be actively working on learning for at least a year before you even consider going for something like the OSCP

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: The other thing to understand is that pentesting/redteaming is probably 90% research and learning. If you don't like learning things, for example referring to the learning portions of THM as "Alot of text and yap that i wont actually apply later on", you may want to think long and hard about whether or not this path is for you

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: There is no such thing as wasted time spent learning. The more information you have, the better equipped you will be to handle new and unique situations

threads.author: annirudha
threads.content: What is reverse engineering?

threads.author: annirudha
threads.content: Like it's a side topic question, not connected to my previous posts.

threads.author: hammerfox
threads.content: reverse engineering is the art of taking compiled binaries and attempting to uncover how the software works

threads.author: annirudha
threads.content: Simplify.

threads.author: hammerfox
threads.content:
that was as simple as i could put it haha
but essentially, when you compile a program into a binary, the binary that's outputted is machine code, you can't really see what the program is meant to do
however through reverse engineering, you may be able to examine it to the point of understanding what's going on with the application

threads.author: hammerfox
threads.content:
as far as i know, reverse engineering a binary won't yield the exact code that was used to make it
but it can be pretty close

threads.author: arity0
threads.content: hacking accounts with exploits just isn't practical, but it is possible

threads.author: arity0
threads.content: but don't expect to be pulling it off any time soon

threads.author: arity0
threads.content: and if it's a big service like, say, instagram, your chances are extremely low

threads.author: arity0
threads.content: you have to keep in mind there are countless extremely talented hackers trying to discover new exploits

threads.author: arity0
threads.content: there's no one way to do it

threads.author: arity0
threads.content: it's different every time

threads.author: arity0
threads.content: finding an exploit is like a lawyer finding a loophole in a law

threads.author: arity0
threads.content: except you can't argue with a computer

threads.author: arity0
threads.content: you just look for flaws and try things until something works

threads.author: arity0
threads.content: with a major service such as instagram, it's going to be quite complicated

threads.author: arity0
threads.content: if you want a basic understanding of how exploits work, look up "buffer overflow" on youtube or something

threads.author: arity0
threads.content: it's one of the most famous types of exploit

threads.author: arity0
threads.content: there's also websites to legally practice your skills, such as hackthebox

threads.author: arity0
threads.content: I should mention, hacking accounts is illegal even if it's your own account

threads.author: arity0
threads.content: because it's still technically hacking their service, which you don't own

threads.author: arity0
threads.content: technically you don't even have rights to your own account on most websites

threads.author: arity0
threads.content: legally speaking, they own it

threads.author: arity0
threads.content: and you're only supposed to access it the way they allow you to

my friend nikola does university level coding but whenever I ask him about these things, he tells me, if I had to go to university to learn this, i dont wanna give you the luxury of knowing these complex things in a matter of minutes, so youre gonna have to pay me to do you favors... now I wish I knew coding sciences myself..

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: This is a pretty common attitude, mostly because what you need to understand is that there is no way to learn those complex concepts in a matter of minutes. People with knowledge can sometimes give you an answer to a single specific problem quickly, but the only way to be able to solve other, similar problems yourself is to go and learn that knowledge

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: If you had the correct knowledge, you can fairly easily do what you want with 100% free tools

Thats why my first question was if it is possible to be done freely, cuz i thought there are charge-free hackers out there who know how to do these things for free in a matter of minutes... then just walk me through on how they did it..

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: It can be done for free, yes. Will you find someone with the knowledge required who will spend their own time to do it for free? Unlikely

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: The thing to understand is that when you say "then just walk me through how they did it" you're missing something huge. I could explain exactly how to do it right now, but you wouldn't understand 99% of what I say
because at first, I had no clue that that whole server consists of freakin Harvard prodigies and proffessors who would only give world class hacking secrets for 50 dollars or more..

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: It's not a secret at all ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è

threads.content: and that's a complete load of horseshit

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: that is someone trying to make themselves feel special
Then they decided to kick me because, supposedly, I was supposed to know from the start that it was a university based server..

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: Most likely the changes you want could be done with a few simple app unpacking tools, a text editor, and if necessary a decompiler like Ghidra, all of which are 100% free
there 3 of them who wanted to see if they could do something but I was not exactly planning to waste 50 dollars on smthing that could had, otherwise, been done for free.

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: The thing to understand is, if you want someone else to do it for you, you're not paying for the tools they use, you're paying for the time and effort they put into gaining the knowledge required to do something like that

threads.author: axjesss
threads.content:
Crafting a CSRF Attack: Crafting a CSRF attack typically involves creating HTML that triggers an HTTP request to the target website. Common methods include: * tags: These can be used for GET requests that might change data on the server. For example: If the bank's transfer function uses a simple GET request without proper CSRF protection, visiting the evil-hacker.com page could unknowingly trigger this transfer. *
submissions: Hidden forms can be automatically submitted using JavaScript, allowing for POST requests with specific data. For example:
Visiting evil-hacker.com would automatically submit this form, potentially changing your email address on legit-bank.com. Why are these external requests "allowed"?

threads.author: axjesss
threads.content:
Visiting evil-hacker.com would automatically submit this form, potentially changing your email address on legit-bank.com.
Why are these external requests "allowed"?
Browsers are designed to follow web standards. When a webpage (like evil-hacker.com) includes resources (like images or triggers form submissions) that point to another domain (legit-bank.com), the browser dutifully fetches or submits those resources, including any relevant cookies for that target domain. This is a fundamental aspect of how the web works ‚Äì allowing different websites to link to and interact with each other.
The vulnerability lies in the target website (legit-bank.com) not being able to distinguish between a legitimate request originating from its own forms and a malicious request triggered by a third-party site, because both carry the same valid session cookie.
Defense Mechanisms:
Modern web frameworks and security best practices employ various techniques to prevent CSRF attacks. The most common is the use of CSRF tokens (also known as synchronizer tokens). Here's how they generally work:
 * When the server generates a form, it includes a unique, unpredictable token as a hidden field.
 * This token is also stored in the user's session.
 * When the form is submitted, the server checks if the received token matches the one stored in the user's session.
 * If the tokens don't match, the request is rejected as potentially forged.
Since a malicious website running on a different domain cannot access the user's session on legit-bank.com, it cannot know or include the correct CSRF token in its forged request. This prevents the attack.
Other defense mechanisms include:
 * SameSite Cookies: This browser security feature allows developers to control whether cookies are sent along with cross-site requests. Setting the SameSite attribute to Strict or Lax can significantly reduce the risk of CSRF.
 *

threads.author: axjesss
threads.content:
Checking the Origin and Referer headers: While not foolproof, servers can examine these headers to get an indication of where the request originated. However, these headers can sometimes be missing or manipulated.
I hope this explanation clarifies how CSRF attacks work and why seemingly external requests can be processed by a target website. It's all about the browser dutifully sending your credentials along with any request, regardless of where that request originates from on the web. Let me know if you have any more questions!

threads.author: axjesss
threads.content:
You've hit on a really insightful point about how these attacks work! Yes, I understand CSRF (Cross-Site Request Forgery) attacks, and I can definitely explain the mechanics behind them, especially addressing your question about how external, malicious servers can seemingly gain the ability to send requests to a legitimate site.
Think of it this way: when you're logged into a website (let's call it legit-bank.com), your browser holds a session cookie that acts like your digital ID. Every time your browser sends a request to legit-bank.com, this cookie is automatically included, proving to the server that it's you.
Now, imagine a malicious website (evil-hacker.com) crafted by an attacker. This site contains some sneaky code ‚Äì maybe an image tag with a src attribute or a hidden form ‚Äì that, when your browser renders the page, triggers a request to legit-bank.com.
Here's the crucial part: your browser will automatically attach the legit-bank.com session cookie to this request originating from evil-hacker.com!
The legit-bank.com server, upon receiving this request, sees a valid session cookie. It has no way of knowing that this request didn't actually originate from you performing an action on its own site. It just sees a request with your credentials.
So, to answer your question directly: the malicious server doesn't inherently have any special privileges to communicate with legit-bank.com. Instead, it tricks your browser into making the privileged request on its behalf, using your existing session cookie.

threads.author: onikibinyedi
threads.content:
Hi everyone,

I‚Äôm currently exploring the idea of running a game server and wanted to include some kind of HWID protection to improve security. I purchased a pre-built system and integrated it into the game, but since I only have usage rights and not the source code, I‚Äôve been doing a series of tests to better understand how it actually works.

I‚Äôve simulated different scenarios ‚Äî even wrote a few basic drivers ‚Äî to see how the protection responds. While I was able to bypass certain versions of it, there‚Äôs one specific layer I haven‚Äôt been able to overcome yet.

I‚Äôm doing this not just out of curiosity, but because I want to fully understand the protection mechanism in order to modify and adapt it for my own server setup.

If anyone here has experience with reverse engineering or analyzing protection systems, I‚Äôd really appreciate any tips, tools, or general guidance you could offer.

Thanks in advance!

threads.author: .eevee
threads.content: http://www.rohitab.com/apimonitor

threads.author: onikibinyedi
threads.content:
Thanks for the suggestion! I‚Äôve used Rohitab‚Äôs API Monitor and done some analysis with x32dbg.

I think the issue is related to a registry value the game writes on first launch, which it checks later to detect changes.

Has anyone seen similar behavior or knows which registry keys are commonly used for HWID checks?

threads.author: onikibinyedi
threads.content: The purpose of this HWID check acts like a limiter, restricting access or usage. This is in the context of the game Metin2 PvP server.

threads.author: .eevee
threads.content:
`HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Cryptography\MachineGuid` spoofable with `sysprep`
`HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\ProductId`
`HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\DigitalProductId`

threads.author: .eevee
threads.content: These are also often usded for fingerprinting devices

threads.author: .eevee
threads.content: Games tend to like using the hard drive IDs from what I've dealt with

threads.content: Guys, I am trying to hack a device that I have installed in VMware using Kali Linux, but how do I hack the https system easily?

threads.content: Theres a lot to unpack there. Are you hosting an intentionally vulnerable service that you can access? Do you know what vulns you would be testing for?

threads.author: infinityrayan
threads.content: Look, I have two systems installed on VMware Workstation Pro, Kali and Windows, and I saw a clip that he was able to decrypt HTTPS with Bettercap using hstshijack/hstshijack, and I tried to do the same, but unfortunately, HTTPS was not decrypted

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: Well, If you want to know why, I recommend learning a bit about the HTTP protocol, learning about TLS, and understanding what HTTPS actually is

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: I'll give you a hint: If it were that easy to decrypt captured HTTPS traffic, the internet wouldn't be a thing.

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: That's not really "decrypting" traffic. That is running a MITM and capturing unencrypted traffic

threads.author: infinityrayan
threads.content: ChatGPT told me that, but I found the matter difficult

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: But again, saying using an MITM is "decrypting HTTPS traffic" is on the level of every terrible clickbait headline out there

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: Yes, so it's running TLS on both connections, but it's not intercepting an existing HTTPS session and decrypting it

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: I'd also say that this isn't really the case... The endpoints 100% realize it, the user might not though

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: both endpoints know 100% full well they are talking with a MITM

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: Yes, and the client will be using the MITM's cert, meaning it knows that it is talking with the MITM

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: like I said, just because they don't alert the user, that doesn't mean they don't know

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: and doing that kind of intercept against a machine you don't control is a whole different ballgame

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: Well, not exactly. This works in some cases, if there isn't certificate pinning in place.

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: Again, the client knows full well that it's using a cert issued and signed by "acme corp trusted interception CA", rather than the actual public trusted CA

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: That was true maybe 15 years ago. It's a bit more complicated now. Initially there was HPKP that would allow pinning of certificates to a certain root or intermediate. This has now been superceded by certificate transparency checking, where the browser will check the certificate against transparency logs. This works in the enterprise side, but makes malicious MITM much more difficult

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: Yes, this is the HUGE caveat to everything you've said

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: Sure, but this won't be seamless like a trusted CA issuing intercept certs

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: The moment you use a self signed that isn't trusted by the client, it becomes GLARINGLY obvious that something fishy is going on

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: I'll give you a hint: If it were that easy to decrypt captured HTTPS traffic, the internet wouldn't be a thing.

threads.author: __cdeclan
threads.content: So when you make a request in the browser it automatically gets forwarded to the MITM, who then makes a TLS connection to the webserver on the endpoints behalf

threads.author: __cdeclan
threads.content: Client sends a hello and receives a cert back, if it‚Äôs trusted then it doesn‚Äôt care or make a distinction of if it‚Äôs a MITM or not

threads.author: __cdeclan

threads.author: bttea
threads.content:
If it were me, I would take your question and ask chatGPT directly.

e.g. : Right now, I'm conducting a penetration test and I‚Äôve already obtained a shell on the target system. Next, I need to escalate privileges ‚Äî could you list some methods or techniques I can use for privilege escalation?

threads.author: bttea
threads.content: No, the point isn‚Äôt about being completely self-reliant ‚Äî it‚Äôs about developing the habit of looking up simple questions on your own first, and only turning to the community for help when you can‚Äôt find a solution.

threads.author: bttea
threads.content:
Many times, you can find the answer just by doing a quick search ‚Äî there‚Äôs really no need to ask, because it‚Äôs often faster than waiting for someone in the community to respond.

Of course, if you have a different perspective, feel free to share and discuss it.

threads.author: bttea
threads.content:
This is actually a topic worth discussing.

Do you truly understand the underlying principles and simply use ChatGPT to save time,
or are you relying on ChatGPT to the point that, without it, you wouldn't be able to accomplish anything?

threads.author: bttea
threads.content: That's why, ever since I first got into the IT field, I've actively sought to understand how things work. Even when answers are available, I still try to verify them‚Äîrather than just making things 'work somehow'.

threads.author: bttea
threads.content: This can also be interpreted as the importance of practice.

threads.content: Whats the difference

threads.author: dogwater3301
threads.content: programming is developing software, applications, websites, etc. by writing instructions in a given programming language and hacking is manipulating and exploiting digital but also physical systems. basically trying to make a thing behave in a way that was not intended by its developers

threads.author: sythor_420
threads.content: Ok

threads.author: sythor_420
threads.content: But hacking is kind of from programming

threads.content: What you recomend I learn?

threads.content: knowing how to program is generally useful FOR hacking but not a bare necessity

threads.content: Also how you learnt code

threads.content: Your right

threads.content: Hacking is mostly malicous

threads.content: Or can I learn hacking without programming

threads.content: hacking itself is a skill, and while not malicious itself, it can be used to do malicious things. you can make a perfectly valid career by hacking companies to help them become more secure for example

threads.content: You‚Äôre right

threads.content: Also what language should I learn

threads.content: hacking requires extensive knowledge of several technical areas. you will not automatically pick up hacking by learning how to program. programming is a skill that can helps understand how systems work and how you can manipulate them. hacking without programming knowledge is really just executing scripts that another person wrote without really knowing what actually is going on.

If I had to pick a specific field of CyberSecurity I'd say pentesting and finding vulnerabilities.
Can you please recommend me some resources to learn from? And what's the best and maybe even fastest path to take?

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: (e.g. tell you to download "tools" full of malware)

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: So typically when someone has "hacked" your phone, what you're dealing with is that they have managed to get you to download and install a malicious app. Once this happens, the best way to deal with it would be to perform a factory reset of the phone.

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: This will ensure that any malicious apps are no longer installed

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: In some rare cases it is, but by far the most likely thing that will happen is either that they get access to accounts of yours by tricking you into entering your username and password into a fake login page (phishing), or you install a malicious app which then gives them access to your phone or computer.

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: When you say his "internet is being hacked" what exactly do you mean?

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: Ah, ok. In that case there are a few options for attacks that don't involve the user clicking on something. The best way to prevent those would be to set a strong password on the wifi network. (12 characters, randomly generated, letters, numbers and symbols)

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: If he legitimately believes that they are compromised, it would be prudent

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: If he is sharing the same password between multiple accounts, and someone compromised one account, they would easily be able to get into any others that share the same password

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: Typically I recommend that you NEVER share passwords across accounts

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: Ah, this is starting to sound more like he may have some issues with paranoia and/or paranoid delusions

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: I would highly suggest that if he isn't already getting help, that you might want to let your mother know, and try to get him to work with a mental health professional

threads.author: arity0
threads.content: malware can still steal your tokens even with a password manager, but it's easy to invalidate tokens

threads.author: arity0
threads.content: on discord you just change your password and it instantly invalidates all tokens

threads.author: arity0
threads.content: so in this scenario, they would still use your token to try to scam other people for a bit but you'd still have the account and you could kick them out

threads.author: arity0
threads.content: on other platforms like google you can just go to security settings and invalidate whatever sessions/tokens you want

threads.content: I use google authenticator

```
Good question ‚Äî I‚Äôll answer carefully and responsibly.

People who create or spread trojans are usually doing malicious things, because trojans are a type of malware. Some common (illegal) uses include:

Stealing data (passwords, credit card numbers, personal files).

Remote access (allowing attackers to control the victim‚Äôs computer).

Installing more malware (like ransomware or cryptominers).

Using the victim‚Äôs computer in botnets (for spam or DDoS attacks).

Surveillance (logging keystrokes, activating webcams, etc.).

‚ö†Ô∏è Important: Using or distributing trojans without permission is cybercrime.

On the defensive side, security researchers and penetration testers may study trojans in a controlled environment to:

Learn how they work (reverse engineering).

Improve antivirus / endpoint detection.

Test defenses in red team exercises.

So the legit, ethical use is for research, education, and improving defenses ‚Äî but in the wild, criminals mainly use them for theft, spying, and sabotage.

üëâ Do you want me to give you a defensive perspective (like how to detect and protect against trojans), or more of a research perspective (like how analysts study them)?
```

threads.author: einfacher
threads.content: Bro, the stuff ur asking (phishing, bans, malware) is basically just illegal. Real hacking is about understanding how systems work. Like yeah, to phish someone u‚Äòd need to know protocols, host servers, clone sites‚Ä¶ but that only comes once u‚Äòve built up al lot of general knowledge. The way u actually get there is by learning a language (python is a good start), understanding networks and massing around with legal labs like hackthebox or tryhackme.

threads.content: what way do you recomend i learn python?

threads.author: x7624
threads.content: the main thing i wanna do is automate stuff ngl

threads.author: x7624
threads.content: because chat gpt just sucks ass at making code

threads.author: einfacher
threads.content:
Maybe get a overview of the language by watching a yt vid but not to long like 10min or something.
Then pick up a project u wanna build (doesn‚Äôt matter how small). Then google/yt/stackoverflow ur way through. Read other ppls code on GitHub and tweak it. Tutorials are fine for the basics but if u only follow them u end up copy pasting code without learning anything.
The real skill is: Beeing stuck, figuring out, making it work.

threads.author: x7624
threads.content: so i watch a vid and instantly try to use it to make sometthing and practice?

threads.author: einfacher
threads.content:
Yup, watch the vid, rebuild it, then change something small (change the style or add a new feature). That way ur not just copying but actually learning how it work. Each time you tweak it u will get stuck and that‚Äôs where the real practice happens.

Ofc there are different way to learn something but this way is fun and that‚Äôs how I got into coding and later Cyber Security

threads.author: lostintheworld75

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: As for "learning software", it seems like maybe you've gotten the mistaken impression that hacking is just about running tools. Hacking really isn't about tools. It's about understanding the systems that you are working with well enough that you can make it do things it wasn't meant to do

threads.content: C2 = Command and Control

threads.content: Yeah, you're not gonna find a lot about how to design malware

threads.author: loredous

threads.author: x1vi_zi
threads.content: One problem I faced personally was hiding the proxy IP from the victims and defenders

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: You can't ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è

threads.author: x1vi_zi
threads.content: even if that machine is somewhere in China

threads.author: x1vi_zi
threads.content: it is still vulnearbale to attacks

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: You can hide it behind another proxy, but that's just pushing the problem out to that next proxy

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: hiding C2 infrastructure is less about trying to actively keep people from seeing where the traffic is going, because that's not possible really. The way that most stealth malware does it, is by trying to blend in with benign traffic

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: i.e. "don't look like C2 traffic"

threads.author: x1vi_zi
threads.content: so its more of a client problem ?

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: no... not really

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: it's a design problem

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: How do you make the traffic to/from your C2 infrastructure look like normal, non-malicious traffic

threads.author: x1vi_zi
threads.content: by making it look like it was never from it

threads.author: x1vi_zi
threads.content: by masking the packets

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: yeah, but that is technically impossible

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: you can't hide traffic

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: it has to cross the network

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: there's nothing you can do about that

threads.content: If this is something you really want to get into as a professional pursuit, I recommend taking some time to deepen your understanding of a lot of fundamentals. Things like networking, application design, basics of security, etc

threads.content: People coming into security always tend to assume that everything is about these hyper-complex, multi-layer systems that try to hide all the bad stuff by making it invisible.

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: There are plenty of blogs and research articles looking at describing known malware C2 frameworks

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: If this is something you really want to get into, my first recommendation is to spend some time learning general security concepts

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: You can't ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: You can hide it behind another proxy, but that's just pushing the problem out to that next proxy

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: hiding C2 infrastructure is less about trying to actively keep people from seeing where the traffic is going, because that's not possible really. The way that most stealth malware does it, is by trying to blend in with benign traffic

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: i.e. "don't look like C2 traffic"

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: no... not really

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: it's a design problem

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: How do you make the traffic to/from your C2 infrastructure look like normal, non-malicious traffic

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: yeah, but that is technically impossible

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: you can't hide traffic

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: it has to cross the network

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: there's nothing you can do about that

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: If this is something you really want to get into as a professional pursuit, I recommend taking some time to deepen your understanding of a lot of fundamentals. Things like networking, application design, basics of security, etc

threads.author: loredous
threads.content:
For example, some novel attempts at C2 have included things like:
- Using information hidden in images posted to social networking sites
- DNS records
- Exfiltrating information in the DATA field of ICMP echo packets

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: Sure, but this is a completely different paradigm. Architecture and systems design is typically about creating optimized systems, designed for best performance

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: Malware C2 isn't about optimization

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: it's about hiding information in plain sight

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: Now you understand why I say "Deepen your knowledge of fundamentals"

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: People coming into security always tend to assume that everything is about these hyper-complex, multi-layer systems that try to hide all the bad stuff by making it invisible.

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: The reality is that 99% of the time, that level of effort isn't worth it, because as a defender, your primary goal isn't "find where the C2 traffic is going" or "Find what the C2 traffic says". It's "block the C2 traffic"

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: Hacking really isn't about the tools

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: They are just a way to make doing certain things easier, but they won't help you unless you actually understand the concepts behind them

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: Instead of learning tools first, learn the technology. Once you have that knowledge, the tools will make complete sense, and you will be able to just look at the help/manpage for a tool and have a pretty good idea of how to use it

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: For example you mentioned wanting to know "what to look for". Until you have knowledge of the actual technology, it's not really possible to tell you what to look for

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: Unless you want a literal list of every possible thing that could be out there

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: If you're interested in learning more, we've got a basic roadmap that gives a decent path for learning the things you need to learn

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: .roadmap

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: With that knowledege, you are really at a point where you need to start directing your own path a bit. It sounds like your long-term goal is to get into doing vulnerability research. My advice would be, as always, make sure you have a solid understanding of the foundations of a lot of the tech that everything relies on these days. Aside from that, you most likely are looking at a similar career/life path to a lot of folks in security. Plan on doing a  few years of lower level work like helpdesk or tech support, maybe spending some time doing sysadmin work, and building a good understanding of the concepts of tech in general, along with building your security knowledge

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: Even outside of career/work focused stuff, you would probably benefit from learning more about how applications are set up and deployed. Many people have a "homelab" for this purpose, and the idea is just to get in there, and get your hands dirty setting things up, breaking them, fixing them, and then breaking them again.

threads.author: arity0
threads.content: google is one of the best tools for osint, it's not just a way to find osint tools

threads.author: arity0
threads.content: and there are tricks to use it more effectively

threads.author: arity0
threads.content: for example, you might just search `johndoe@gmail.com` but if you want better results then you can add quotation marks to ensure it looks for exact matches

threads.author: arity0
threads.content: like `"johndoe@gmail.com"`

threads.author: arity0
threads.content: or for example, there's someone known as `john_doe69` on discord and you're trying to find his instagram account, but the instagram account `john_doe69` isn't his. so maybe you'd search `john_doe site:instagram.com` and find an account called `john_doe420`. and oh hey, it happens to be the same guy

threads.author: arity0
threads.content: not saying that's the best way to find accounts on instagram, it's just an example of how powerful google search can be

threads.author: 0xf00sec
threads.content: Recon gotta be objective driven, no aimless poking. Ask up front what am I trying to achieve? Mapping? API discovery? logic enumeration? Auth/authz flows? Something else?

threads.author: 0xf00sec
threads.content: rcn is just the info gathering phase, enumerate as much as you can then use that intel to ask is an attack even possible here? Could I pull an injection at this endpoint? What would stop me, what would let it happen and why? Run those scenarios in your head.

threads.author: nelideven
threads.content: cbc, ecb, gcm, ctr are just mode-of operations, basically since AES encryption only supports 16 byte encryption, the workaround is those mode-of operations (cmiiw)

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: Well, they're different ways of using the AES algorithm to encrypt data.

threads.author: loredous

threads.author: loredous

threads.author: nelideven

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: Sample rate is all about converting analog signals (audio) to digital representations

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: For example, if you have a file that is 16 bit samples, at a sample rate of 44khz, that just means that 44,000 times per second, the Analog to Digital conversion process is taking a sample of that audio waveform, and representing it as a 16 bit number

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: My advice to you would be: It sounds like you have a genuine interest in cybersecurity. If you don't get this specific internship, there will be others in the future. To better prepare yourself for those future opportunities, I highly recommend you set aside time to learn the basic concepts behind all of these processes. Cybersecurity isn't about learning to use tools. Tools are irrelevant. If you don't understand what the tool you are using is actually doing, you're in a very bad place.

Buffer overflows, you're honestly going to work more in Assembly than C. OSCP you don't really need C for, and if I had to chose a single programming language that is most valuable there, Python.

threads.author: _cosmicecho
threads.content:
(u can ignore this if u like)

Hi, this is not really a general hacking question, but more about "if my OpSec in this app is already compromised by hackers" question.

I was in this mobile app game that I left 2 years ago but I have 4 years of playing since the start of the Pandemic (2020).

My question is, in this mobile application video game, I encountered around 3 years ago that someone had managed to bypass my clan's "join system", so there are 2 security measures in place. (Number 1) Did the player met the  requirements of the clan - Yes they do, (Number 2) Was the player authorized to join the clan, because keep in mind this clan sets the requirement to "Request to join" meaning if a high ranking member did not authorize the player to join regardless of whether or not they passed the clan's requirements, they are not allowed to join - to put it simply, they managed to join without this second requirement.

So, I just want to know what kind of exploit does it take to perform this action. 

and since then my clan's join requirements are already at the threshold that no player can achieve so even if I am away no one is able to perform this exploit again (most likely patched quietly by the developers)

In this same game people use Proxy Payments, specifically they use a different region to have a different price in their microtransactions (because some regions have a lower price than that in the U.S.)

I asked Gemini first and it call it an "Authorization Bypass", and second is the "Region Exploitation" that bypasses Region Lock, Initiated a purchase, and Server Validation Failure.

At that time I never used a VPN because I do not know anything about Cybersecurity yet (LOL) and I actually used my personal email for this game. However, my concern is not that the developers know my identity, my concern is that if those who targeted me before has access to my personal data that is used to play that game.

Thank You!!

threads.author: earthtoshan
threads.content:
hi guys,
I am pretty rookie, done my compTIAs and started a little hack the box.

My friend online is getting some pretty unacceptable comments from sharing her life story, and I just want to run some harmless OSINT to check the usernames and see which platforms they are on, just build a little intel. I reckon they may all be the same person, if it is then calling them out would shut it down pretty quick I reckon.

As far as I know doing OSINT on cyber bullies is ethical, and I intend to stay ethical, I don't intend to doxx them or anything, I just want to use this as an opportunity to brush up on my cyber sec and maybe help a friend out at the same time, if you agree can you help me figure out which tools I can run to check which platforms or websites have this username?

So far I have consulted chatGPT and tried maigret, spiderfoot (passive), and sherlock - but these have all run dry for me every time.
I think its something to do with the endpoints recognising that it is a bot and just returning no data.
So I assume running these tools vanilla is a deprecated method.

threads.author: dex1m.
threads.content:
> SECTION 5 - Where should I start?
> This is the question that most people ask. I honestly don't think there is any one place to start. Ask around on any forum and people will always tell you to learn to use RAT's and keyloggers. To be honest I wouldn't recommend doing that straight away. I would advise to learn the basic terminologies of hacking (see section 6) and try to get an idea of exactly what everything means. It's really important to understand stuff before you go downloading random hacking programs from the Internet. It you don't know how to use them, or if they are viruses, you only have yourself to blame.

if you ask me, just learn what hacking is I can give you a section to what it means. but check out the #‚ö°ÔΩúresources . 

go with basics enjoy your time using linux,cli,nvim,,finger keyboards responsivilities, programing coding, screwing around with the computer. asking chat asking ai doing ideas. 

then start the basic form of hacking which is computer hacking. it's the easier way to visualize the art of hacking.

threads.author: dex1m.
threads.content:
> SECTION 3 - What is hacking?
> What is hacking? Well, whatishacking.org defines it as "the practice of modifying the features of a system, in order to accomplish a goal outside of the creator's original purpose. The person who is consistently engaging in hacking activities, and has accepted hacking as a lifestyle and philosophy of their choice, is called a hacker. Computer hacking is the most popular form of hacking nowadays, especially in the field of computer security, but hacking exists in many other forms, such as phone hacking, brain hacking, etc. and it's not limited to either of them." - Taken from whatishacking.org That's a great definition but in my opinion hacking is much more than that. In my opinion, hacking isn't something you can just 'learn'. It's not just a skill, it's an art. Hacking requires knowledge. Knowledge is power. In order to gain said knowledge, and the power that comes with it, a change of lifestyle is required, along with a certain amount of secrecy. Learning 'how' to hack takes time and dedication. There's no easy way to get better at it. That's right, no shortcuts and its unlikely you're going to get a helping hand. Like everything else in life, it takes practice. Don't go crying to others if it doesn't work out, just keep calm and carry on. If you are serious about becoming a hacker, you will need to be willing to change your lifestyle, and dedicate yourself to the task. With enough dedication and hard work you will excel at hacking.

Don't take those sections seriously they might or might not be correct. don't take my words seriously too they may or may not be correct. I just found those in my notes and happend to share them with you

threads.author: _cosmicecho
threads.content:
An effective DDoS only works if someone has a massive size of botnets that they have the computing power to execute a lot of network communications.

Anyway, you won't get doxxed by simple username if it doesn't match your real name, unless you put a giveaway information in both your messages and bio, usually you cannot get doxxed because data is encrypted on traffic if the backend and client supports encryption, only when you have an infostealer or any kind of malware/spyware that has infected your device and those malware manages to compromise sensitive information that is in your endpoint, that's only when the hacker gets the information back to their servers

threads.author: _cosmicecho
threads.content: Plus, if you connect to a Rogue Access Point or compromised/malicious router, hackers can trick you into social engineering by hijacking your DNS and redirecting you to their clone websites to make you give out your information

threads.author: _cosmicecho
threads.content: But usually they can't do this if your traffic is encrypted, most of it is, if they ever were intercepting your data they can only see the metadata of the encryption which has both the source and destination IP

threads.author: _cosmicecho
threads.content: A VPN is a strong defense against this as it will only give out the destination IP to the VPN server

threads.author: _cosmicecho
threads.content: But only when you want to maximize your privacy, an operating system already has built in TLS. Im using TLS 1.2

threads.author: _cosmicecho
threads.content: Remember, always use encrypted DNS

threads.author: _cosmicecho
threads.content: Now i still don't know mechanics behind certificates but you receive their certificate for encryption from any software or any website you're connecting to, that's how your traffic gets encrypted

threads.author: _cosmicecho
threads.content:
oh I remember now, its called something like DNSSEC, which is already a feature in most DNS service providers, even public ones like 8.8.8.8, UltraDNS, Quad9, and OpenDNS

https://quad9.net/service/service-addresses-and-features/#unsec

But I said "encrypted" because you have to be careful of your own DNS configuration. If your device says your DNS is (unencrypted), then it is unencrypted regardless of your DNS service

threads.author: _cosmicecho
threads.content:
i never tried this before reverting back to my old DNS, but maybe this can help in the configuration, or learn to configure other DNS
https://docs.quad9.net/Setup_Guides/Windows/Windows_11_%28Encrypted%29/

threads.content: yep, it encrypted it lol

threads.author: raxelcoder
threads.content: What do network-enabled attacks mean and what are some examples? I didn't seem to find any relevant information.

threads.author: mrsskelli
threads.content:
A network-enabled attack is an attack that either:
    1.    Exploits vulnerabilities in network protocols, services, or configurations, or
    2.    Uses network connectivity as a vector to deliver, coordinate, or propagate the attack.


It depends on context really

threads.author: bttea
threads.content: You can review the attack categories listed by CWE, or use a CVSS 3.1 calculator. The calculator enumerates risk-assessment options for each vulnerability; by looking at those options you can infer the types of weakness scenarios that may occur.

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: Honestly, I think people have a really screwed up view on school and education in general. The point of school isn't to force you to remember a bunch of stuff, so that you can recall specific names and dates and places. The point is to expose you to a huge amount of information while you are still young and your brain is as pliable as possible.

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: If your teachers are just making you do rote memorization tasks, they're shitty teachers.

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: They should be teaching you the "why" behind things

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: who gives a fuck what year this or that war began and ended. That's not really all that important. The important part is WHY did it start?

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: The when and who are really only important in general terms, to set the specific general conditions

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: but what does it matter if a war started in 1914, or 1915, or 1913?

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: As long as you understand the general era and what the prevailing conditions were, that's the important part

threads.author: loredous
threads.content: Exactly
